chat_messages.text:
So after refusing to allow Crest to do the scaffolding and render removal before I see the report, I finally got it from Crest's new regional manager, Charlie Joseph, yesterday.

I've attached it.

I sent the following email to Crest's CEO Martyn Clark and the NHOS yesterday afternoon:

"Dear Mr. Clark,
The MJA Consulting report regarding 10 Colt View, which Crest Nicholson commissioned only at my insistence on a professional assessment, confirms what I have suspected and stated since January 2024: the render defects are not minor settlement, as Crest repeatedly asserted, but stem from fundamental construction issues.
For 18 months, my valid concerns about the cracking render were dismissed. Astonishingly, Crest Nicholson then agreed to a full re-render, framing it as a "gesture of goodwill," without any prior professional structural assessment to determine the root cause. Your company was seemingly prepared to undertake costly, disruptive work that, according to your own appointed experts (MJA Consulting), would likely fail again due to the lack of necessary movement joints.
This MJA report now irrefutably exposes that Crest Nicholson's proposed "goodwill" re-render, without addressing the underlying structural deficiencies, would have been a superficial fix, merely delaying the inevitable re-cracking and early failure of the render, quite possibly beyond the initial two-year warranty period that Crest would be responsible within. This is not "goodwill"; it appears to be a calculated attempt to avoid addressing a more serious and costly construction defect.
The report also highlights that Crest’s initial "assessments" were incorrect. Your company's handling of this complaint has been characterized by neglect. This pattern of dismissing legitimate issues, only to propose inadequate solutions or concede under duress, is unacceptable and falls far short of the New Homes Quality Code. It proves my complaint was valid under NHOS guidelines from the outset over 500 days ago.
You, as the new CEO, and presumably aware of the history concerning our previous property, had the opportunity to ensure this was handled with competence and integrity. Instead, the approach has been one of consistent dismissal and attempts to downplay serious concerns. Claiming the house was built to NHBC standards while being unable to produce those standards for the NHOS further compounds this. *You* are ultimately responsible for this.
This MJA report, demonstrating the need for structural interventions like movement joints, and this correspondence, are being copied to the NHOS. It is clear evidence of Crest Nicholson’s attempt to avoid proper rectification and their ongoing mismanagement.
Mr. Taylor"

Based on my comprehensive search of your Gmail, I found substantial email correspondence regarding Plot 34 / 10 Colt View between you, Crest Nicholson, and NHOS. Here's a summary of what I discovered:

## **Key Email Threads Found:**

### **1. Crest Nicholson Correspondence (Plot 34/10 Colt View - Render Issues)**
- **Main thread**: Multiple emails from April-May 2025 discussing render crack repairs
- **Key contacts**: Donna Hack (Customer Service Manager), Customer Service SO
- **Timeline**: Ongoing scheduling of independent surveyor (Robert Fleming, MJA Consulting Civil & Structural Engineers) to inspect render crack
- **Latest status**: Surveyor visit was scheduled and confirmed for May 22, 2025

### **2. NHOS Case NHOS-2024-000512**
- **Case subject**: 10 Colt View render and other issues
- **Status**: With ombudsman for decision
- **Key developments**:
  - Case accepted January 2025
  - Allocated to ombudsman March 31, 2025
  - Developer responses received April 2025 (with large PDF attachments)
  - Additional information requested from both parties
  - You submitted photos and rebuttals in April-May 2025

### **3. Key Issues Identified:**
1. **Render crack** - recurring issue that Crest initially said they wouldn't fix further, but later agreed to address
2. **Path/footpath work** - additional planning permission issues on development site
3. **NHBC standards** - questions about construction standards used

### **4. Large Email Attachments Found:**
Several emails contain significant PDF attachments (3MB+, 14MB+, 30MB+), particularly:
- NHOS emails from April 22 and May 20, 2025 containing developer responses
- Your emails to NHOS with supporting documentation and photos

## **Limitation:**
Unfortunately, I cannot access or analyze the PDF attachments directly through Gmail. The attachments appear to contain:
- Crest Nicholson's formal responses to NHOS
- Planning documentation and drawings
- Photos of render damage
- Technical reports and correspondence

## **Next Steps:**
To review the PDF attachments, you would need to:
1. Download them directly from your Gmail
2. Use Desktop Commander to read local PDF files if you save them to your computer
3. Or provide specific questions about content you remember from the attachments

Would you like me to help you with any specific aspect of this correspondence, or would you prefer to download and analyze any particular PDF attachments using Desktop Commander?

{"id": "193e03b501b94e16", "threadId": "193df245998bac21", "labelIds": ["Label_795682206024893516", "IMPORTANT", "STARRED", "CATEGORY_PERSONAL", "INBOX"], "snippet": "Good afternoon, Mr Taylor I have just logged onto the Winchester City Council website and believe the link below will direct you to the information you require. 23/01670/NMA | (Non-Material Amendment", "payload": {"partId": "", "mimeType": "multipart/alternative", "filename": "", "headers": [{"name": "Delivered-To", "value": "paulroberttaylor@gmail.com"}, {"name": "From", "value": "Customer Service SO <CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com>"}, {"name": "To", "value": "Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>"}, {"name": "Subject", "value": "0034 Albany Wood Digger and wood left on open area"}, {"name": "Date", "value": "Thu, 19 Dec 2024 18:43:18 +0000"}], "body": {"size": 0, "data": "Good afternoon, Mr Taylor I have just logged onto the Winchester City Council website and believe the link below will direct you to the information you require. 23/01670/NMA | (Non-Material Amendment to original Planning Consent 16/01322/FUL) Concerning the Finished Levels of the Informal Open Green Space to the South-eastern Extent of the Development known as Albany Wood. | Land To The West Of Tangier Lane Bishops Waltham Hampshire<https://planningapps.winchester.gov.uk/online-applications/applicationDetails.do?activeTab=documents&keyVal=RXMYZKBPGSO00> Kind Regards Donna Hack Customer Service Manager Crest Nicholson South, 500 Dashwood Lang Road, Bourne Business Park, Addlestone, Surrey KT15 2HJ customerserviceso@crestnicholson.com<mailto:customerserviceso@crestnicholson.com> From: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com> Sent: 19 December 2024 14:22 To: Customer Service SO <CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com> Subject: Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: 0034 Albany Wood Digger and wood left on open area Good afternoon, Thank you for this. Please could you specify one of the plans showing this work? Mr Taylor On Thu, 19 Dec 2024, 14:07 Customer Service SO, <CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com<mailto:CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com>> wrote: Good afternoon, Mr Taylor Please try 23/01670/NMA, my apologies I put M first instead of N Kind Regards Donna Hack Customer Service Manager Crest Nicholson South, 500 Dashwood Lang Road<https://www.google.com/maps/search/500+Dashwood+Lang+Road?entry=gmail&source=g>, Bourne Business Park, Addlestone, Surrey KT15 2HJ customerserviceso@crestnicholson.com<mailto:customerserviceso@crestnicholson.com> From: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com<mailto:paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>> Sent: 19 December 2024 13:57 To: Customer Service SO <CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com<mailto:CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com>> Subject: [EXTERNAL] Re: 0034 Albany Wood Digger and wood left on open area Good afternoon, Thank you for your email however the application number given returns no results (screenshot attached). Mr Taylor [cid:image001.png@01DB521F.4DC60B10] On Thu, 19 Dec 2024 at 13:38, Customer Service SO <CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com<mailto:CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com>> wrote: Good afternoon, Mr Taylor We advise that you refer to the Winchester City Council website, under planning application you can view application -23/01670/MNA, this will direct you to the application submitted by Crest Nicholson which includes drawings showing the footpath/s and the small circular finishing points. Kind Regards Donna Hack Customer Service Manager Crest Nicholson South, 500 Dashwood Lang Road<https://www.google.com/maps/search/500+Dashwood+Lang+Road?entry=gmail&source=g>, Bourne Business Park, Addlestone, Surrey KT15 2HJ customerserviceso@crestnicholson.com<mailto:customerserviceso@crestnicholson.com> From: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com<mailto:paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>> Sent: 18 December 2024 16:33 To: Customer Service SO <CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com<mailto:CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com>>; Mark Foyle <Mark.Foyle@crestnicholson.com<mailto:Mark.Foyle@crestnicholson.com>> Subject: Fwd: [EXTERNAL] Fwd: Digger and wood left on open area Good afternoon, Please could you provide me with the link of the plan on the WCC planning site which shows the recently built path, as per previous emails. Mr Taylor ---------- Forwarded message --------- From: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com<mailto:paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>> Date: Tue, 17 Dec 2024 at 13:17 Subject: Re: [EXTERNAL] Fwd: Digger and wood left on open area To: Customer Service SO <CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com<mailto:CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com>> Cc: Mark Foyle <Mark.Foyle@crestnicholson.com<mailto:Mark.Foyle@crestnicholson.com>> Good afternoon, This diagram unfortunately shows nothing of value. Please forward a larger section of the plan, and a link as to where I can view the full document. I specifically asked which plan given to the planning department at Winchester County Council shows this work, but I am still waiting for this despite repeated requests. Please provide the url or planning permission document ID that enables me to view this plan on the WCC website. Mr Taylor On Tue, 17 Dec 2024 at 13:12, Customer Service SO <CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com<mailto:CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com>> wrote: Good afternoon, Mr Taylor Following your enquiry below, please see the following for your reference: Drawing number 2572 -A-1006-A. also below showing the pathway that is being built in/finished. Kind Regards Donna Hack Customer Service Manager Crest Nicholson South, 500 Dashwood Lang Road<https://www.google.com/maps/search/500+Dashwood+Lang+Road?entry=gmail&source=g>, Bourne Business Park, Addlestone, Surrey KT15 2HJ customerserviceso@crestnicholson.com<mailto:customerserviceso@crestnicholson.com> From: Customer Service SO <CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com<mailto:CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com>> Sent: 16 December 2024 13:53 To: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com<mailto:paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>>; Customer Service SO <CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com<mailto:CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com>>; Mark Foyle <Mark.Foyle@crestnicholson.com<mailto:Mark.Foyle@crestnicholson.com>> Subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] Fwd: Digger and wood left on open area Good afternoon, Mr Taylor Thank you for your email. Your enquiry is being viewed and we will come back to you within 5 working days, as previously advised, the works will be completed by the end of this week, if not before and the equipment taken away. Kind Regards Donna Hack Customer Service Manager Crest Nicholson South, 500 Dashwood Lang Road<https://www.google.com/maps/search/500+Dashwood+Lang+Road?entry=gmail&source=g>, Bourne Business Park, Addlestone, Surrey KT15 2HJ customerserviceso@crestnicholson.com<mailto:customerserviceso@crestnicholson.com> From: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com<mailto:paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>> Sent: 16 December 2024 13:09 To: Customer Service SO <CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com<mailto:CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com>>; Mark Foyle <Mark.Foyle@crestnicholson.com<mailto:Mark.Foyle@crestnicholson.com>> Subject: Re: [EXTERNAL] Fwd: Digger and wood left on open area Good afternoon, I would like to know which plan submitted to Winchester County Council shows the work currently being carried out. Mr Taylor On Fri, 13 Dec 2024, 13:32 Paul Taylor, <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com<mailto:paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>> wrote: Good afternoon, Please could I have a response to my previous email. Mr Taylor ---------- Forwarded message --------- From: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com<mailto:paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>> Date: Thu, 12 Dec 2024, 13:30 Subject: Re: [EXTERNAL] Fwd: Digger and wood left on open area To: Customer Service SO <CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com<mailto:CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com>> Good afternoon, The work currently being done must be on a plan or plans submitted to the council at some point. I would like to know which plan or diagram this work relates to. content.title: NHOS-2024-000512 | Case allocated to Ombudsman for draft decision.

content.text:
Based on my comprehensive search of your Gmail, I found substantial email correspondence regarding Plot 34 / 10 Colt View between you, Crest Nicholson, and NHOS. Here's a summary of what I discovered:

## **Key Email Threads Found:**

### **1. Crest Nicholson Correspondence (Plot 34/10 Colt View - Render Issues)**
- **Main thread**: Multiple emails from April-May 2025 discussing render crack repairs
- **Key contacts**: Donna Hack (Customer Service Manager), Customer Service SO
- **Timeline**: Ongoing scheduling of independent surveyor (Robert Fleming, MJA Consulting Civil & Structural Engineers) to inspect render crack
- **Latest status**: Surveyor visit was scheduled and confirmed for May 22, 2025

### **2. NHOS Case NHOS-2024-000512**
- **Case subject**: 10 Colt View render and other issues
- **Status**: With ombudsman for decision
- **Key developments**:
  - Case accepted January 2025
  - Allocated to ombudsman March 31, 2025
  - Developer responses received April 2025 (with large PDF attachments)
  - Additional information requested from both parties
  - You submitted photos and rebuttals in April-May 2025

### **3. Key Issues Identified:**
1. **Render crack** - recurring issue that Crest initially said they wouldn't fix further, but later agreed to address
2. **Path/footpath work** - additional planning permission issues on development site
3. **NHBC standards** - questions about construction standards used

### **4. Large Email Attachments Found:**
Several emails contain significant PDF attachments (3MB+, 14MB+, 30MB+), particularly:
- NHOS emails from April 22 and May 20, 2025 containing developer responses
- Your emails to NHOS with supporting documentation and photos

## **Limitation:**
Unfortunately, I cannot access or analyze the PDF attachments directly through Gmail. The attachments appear to contain:
- Crest Nicholson's formal responses to NHOS
- Planning documentation and drawings
- Photos of render damage
- Technical reports and correspondence

## **Next Steps:**
To review the PDF attachments, you would need to:
1. Download them directly from your Gmail
2. Use Desktop Commander to read local PDF files if you save them to your computer
3. Or provide specific questions about content you remember from the attachments

Would you like me to help you with any specific aspect of this correspondence, or would you prefer to download and analyze any particular PDF attachments using Desktop Commander?

Based on my comprehensive search through your Gmail, I found very limited email correspondence that specifically describes waiting for move-in dates with boxes packed for months. Here's what I can summarize from the available emails:

## **Summary of Move-In Date Issues Found:**

### **Move-In Day - December 18, 2023:**
The email thread from December 18, 2023 shows the actual move-in day challenges:

**Key Timeline:**
- **2:24 PM**: You requested keys to begin moving in 
- **2:28 PM**: Eileen Guihen replied that keys couldn't be released until legal completion, but offered access to "start off loading while we wait"
- **2:40 PM**: You complained they only gave garage access, which wasn't useful
- **2:47 PM**: You insisted on house access, not just garage
- **2:51 PM**: You specifically mentioned "**We are supposed to have the keys at 1pm**"
- **2:54 PM**: Eileen confirmed the sales office was opening the house, stating "Keys are never released prior to legal completion"

### **Build Delays Leading Up to Move-In:**
From the November 2023 emails, there's evidence of prolonged delays:

**November 23, 2023** (draft email):
- You mentioned being "almost a full calendar month since you advised the property would be ready to move in"
- Reference to your son's health issues and not being able to tell him when you'd be settled
- Statement: "We have done everything we are able to, including having the message to the NHBC ready with our solicitors"

**Earlier November 2023 emails show:**
- Multiple Trinity Rose inspections being rescheduled
- DPC (Damp Proof Course) work needing completion
- Issues with Stage 12 inspections
- Quality concerns that were supposed to be resolved before move-in

### **Key Issues Identified:**
1. **Scheduled vs. Actual**: You were supposed to have keys at 1pm on December 18th, but legal completion hadn't occurred
2. **Repeated Delays**: References to being "almost a full calendar month" past when the property was supposed to be ready
3. **Family Impact**: Mentions of your son's health and not being able to provide certainty about moving dates
4. **Build Quality**: Ongoing issues that were supposed to be resolved pre-completion

### **Missing Information:**
However, I did **not find specific emails** that detail:
- The exact duration boxes were packed
- Multiple date changes over months
- Specific correspondence about repeatedly postponed completion dates

This suggests that either:
1. These discussions happened via phone calls rather than email
2. The emails predate January 2023 (outside my search range)
3. They may be in threads that don't contain the search terms I used

Would you like me to search with different terms or timeframes to find more specific correspondence about the repeated date changes and packed boxes situation?

{"id": "194b758115f89265", "threadId": "193de5c6f63a86d3", "labelIds": ["SENT"], "snippet": "Mr. Foyle / Mr. Clark, It has now been over a calendar month, and I have still not received a response. The legal agreement between us contains clear stipulations that apply to both parties. I have", "payload": {"partId": "", "mimeType": "multipart/alternative", "filename": "", "headers": [{"name": "Date", "value": "Thu, 30 Jan 2025 13:13:07 +0000"}, {"name": "Subject", "value": "Re: 25 Abbotts Road NDA"}, {"name": "From", "value": "Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>"}, {"name": "To", "value": "Mark Foyle <Mark.Foyle@crestnicholson.com>, Martyn Clark <martyn.clark@crestnicholson.com>"}], "body": {"size": 0, "data": "Mr. Foyle / Mr. Clark, It has now been over a calendar month, and I have still not received a response. The legal agreement between us contains clear stipulations that apply to both parties. I have fully adhered to my obligations under the agreement, but the same cannot be said for Crest Nicholson. As the agreement explicitly states, consent to discuss its terms *must not be unreasonably withheld.* Crest has failed to provide any reasonable justification for its refusal, beyond a blanket denial, despite multiple requests. As such, Crest is not upholding the terms of its own agreement. The continued lack of response only reinforces that Crest is not committed to the agreement it drafted. Without compliance from both parties, the enforceability of the agreement itself is called into question. I expect a response without further delay. Mr. Taylor On Thu, 19 Dec 2024 at 10:02, Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com> wrote: > Dear Mr. Foyle, > > I am writing to address once more the matter of the NDA and Crest\u2019s > refusal to grant permission for me to discuss its contents with the NHOS. > As per the agreement, consent to such discussions \"shall not be > unreasonably withheld.\" > > Despite repeated requests, you have provided no reason\u2014let alone a valid > justification\u2014for this refusal. This lack of transparency raises > significant concerns about Crest\u2019s adherence to the terms of the NDA and > the enforceability of the agreement. > > To prevent any misunderstanding, I want to make it explicitly clear that I > have strictly adhered to the terms of the NDA and have not disclosed its > contents to the NHOS or any other third party. My requests for permission > to do so have been made in good faith, with a justified reason: to > demonstrate Crest\u2019s broader pattern of behavior, which is central to my > ongoing issues. This is a legitimate and reasonable request, and under the > terms set out by Crest, cannot be refused without a valid and detailed > justification. > > If necessary, I can demonstrate repeated attempts to request permission in > accordance with the terms signed by both myself and Crest. However, Crest\u2019s > continued refusal without any valid explanation appears inconsistent with > the terms of the NDA as written. This raises concerns about the > enforceability of the agreement if one party fails to uphold its > obligations. > > To ensure compliance with the NDA, I request the following by 5 January > 2025: > > 1. Written confirmation of permission to discuss the NDA with the > NHOS, or > 2. A detailed explanation providing a valid and reasonable > justification for withholding consent, as explicitly required by the NDA. > > I trust that Crest will address this matter promptly and reaffirm its > commitment to the agreement\u2019s terms and spirit. > > Kind regards, > Mr. Taylor >"}, "parts": []}, "sizeEstimate": 7251, "historyId": "16853131", "internalDate": "1738242787000"}

content.text: {"id": "1933f2f89dfb0a2d", "threadId": "192e85c84e501867", "labelIds": ["SENT"], "snippet": "Dear Ms Marioni, Thank you for acknowledging receipt of my email to Mr. Clark. To help streamline things, I wanted to clarify that my two immediate requests are: A copy of the inspection report for the", "payload": {"partId": "", "mimeType": "multipart/alternative", "filename": "", "headers": [{"name": "Date", "value": "Mon, 18 Nov 2024 12:11:40 +0000"}, {"name": "Subject", "value": "Re: FW: [EXTERNAL] Fwd: 0034 Albany Wood"}, {"name": "From", "value": "Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>"}, {"name": "To", "value": "Beth Marioni <Beth.Marioni@crestnicholson.com>"}], "body": {"size": 0, "data": "Dear Ms Marioni, Thank you for acknowledging receipt of my email to Mr. Clark. To help streamline things, I wanted to clarify that my two immediate requests are: 1. A copy of the inspection report for the render repair, so I can understand how it was deemed acceptable. 2. A decision regarding whether I can disclose the NDA-covered experience at 25 Abbots Road to the NHOS. I understand Mr. Clark is considering my email in full, but a swift response on these two points would greatly help in progressing matters. Thank you again for your assistance, and I look forward to hearing from you. Kind regards, Mr Taylor On Fri, 15 Nov 2024 at 15:54, Beth Marioni <Beth.Marioni@crestnicholson.com> wrote: > Dear Mr Taylor, > > > > Mr Clark has asked me to acknowledge receipt of your email below. He is > current out of the office, but will respond to you early next week. > > > > Kindest regards > > Beth > > > > *Beth Marioni* > > *Executive Assistant to Penny Thomas, Group Company Secretary* > > *Executive Assistant to Kenny Duncan, Managing Director of Strategic Land* > > > > *M: 07816 091764 * > > Crest Nicholson, 500 Dashwood Lang Road, Bourne Business Park, Addlestone, > Surrey, KT15 2HJ > www.crestnicholson.com > > > > *From:* Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com> > *Sent:* 14 November 2024 10:53 > *To:* Martyn Clark <Martyn.Clark@Crestnicholson.com> > *Subject:* [EXTERNAL] Fwd: 0034 Albany Wood > > > [STOP: This email originated from outside Crest Nicholson. THINK BEFORE > YOU CLICK: Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognise > the sender and know the content is safe. Do not enter your ID and Password > and think before you accept any Multi Factor Authentication prompt.] > > Mr. Clark, > > I am writing to address the ongoing issue concerning the render repair at > my property. From the outset, it was made clear to Crest Nicholson\u2019s > representative, with the Weber representative present, that the expectation > for any repair was to achieve an as-new finish with no visible evidence of > prior issues. > > Yet, a repair method was chosen that, as now acknowledged, could never > meet this standard. This critical limitation was not disclosed to me before > work began. Only after completion was it explained that the chosen repair > would not result in a seamless finish, contrary to what any new homeowner > would expect. The suggestion that Crest Nicholson did not consider this > standard implicit for a new home is disappointing, to say the least. > > Additionally, it was stated by Mark Foyle that a joint inspection of the > repair would take place with both Crest and myself. No such joint review > occurred. Instead, a staff member evidently inspected the work without my > knowledge or consent, as the repair is only visible from the scaffolding, > requiring access to my property. Had I been present, I would have made it > clear immediately that the repair did not meet my expressly stated > expectations for a seamless finish. > > I am also not going to have a meeting with senior Crest management > regarding this issue, and I do not wish to have to keep repeating this > decision. Based on past experiences with Crest, in-person meetings are > rarely pleasant. > > To pre-empt any attempt by Crest to characterize my refusal to meet as > \u201cuncooperative\u201d\u2014for example, \u201cMr. Taylor refused to meet with Crest > representatives. We tried to manage this, but the customer was > uncooperative\u201d\u2014I formally request, as per the NDA for 25 Abbots Road, > permission to disclose our experience with Crest at the previous property > to the NHOS. This would provide necessary context regarding my discomfort > with in-person meetings with senior Crest staff. > > Frankly, I am astounded that a CEO would sanction this substandard > solution, especially knowing what Crest put my family through previously at > 25 Abbots Road. To then send the very build director responsible for that > previous property to try to \u201cdiscuss\u201d their way out of doing a proper job > here is both inappropriate and insulting. > > I am further astounded that Crest Nicholson would knowingly sanction a > solution that could not ensure a consistent, as-new finish. It is genuinely > absurd to now be debating whether the repair should achieve this level\u2014this > should be the baseline for any reputable builder. The continued insistence > on further visits to \u201cdiscuss\u201d this only prolongs what is a straightforward > matter of quality. Any defense of a visibly subpar repair\u2014particularly by > invoking NHBC\u2019s absolute minimum standards\u2014only reinforces a reluctance to > provide the standard of work that any new homeowner would expect. > > In addition to a request for permission to discuss the experience of 25 > Abbots Road with the NHOS, I am also formally requesting a copy of the > inspection report produced by your staff member following their visit to > our property. THINK BEFORE YOU CLICK: Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognise the sender and know the content is safe. Do not enter your ID and Password and think before you accept any Multi Factor Authentication prompt.] Mr. Clark, I am writing to address the ongoing issue concerning the render repair at my property. From the outset, it was made clear to Crest Nicholson's representative, with the Weber representative present, that the expectation for any repair was to achieve an as-new finish with no visible evidence of prior issues. Yet, a repair method was chosen that, as now acknowledged, could never meet this standard. This critical limitation was not disclosed to me before work began. Only after completion was it explained that the chosen repair would not result in a seamless finish, contrary to what any new homeowner would expect. The suggestion that Crest Nicholson did not consider this standard implicit for a new home is disappointing, to say the least. Additionally, it was stated by Mark Foyle that a joint inspection of the repair would take place with both Crest and myself. No such joint review occurred. Instead, a staff member evidently inspected the work without my knowledge or consent, as the repair is only visible from the scaffolding, requiring access to my property. Had I been present, I would have made it clear immediately that the repair did not meet my expressly stated expectations for a seamless finish. I am also not going to have a meeting with senior Crest management regarding this issue, and I do not wish to have to keep repeating this decision. Based on past experiences with Crest, in-person meetings are rarely pleasant. To pre-empt any attempt by Crest to characterize my refusal to meet as \"uncooperative\"-for example, \"Mr. Taylor refused to meet with Crest representatives. We tried to manage this, but the customer was uncooperative\"-I formally request, as per the NDA for 25 Abbots Road, permission to disclose our experience with Crest at the previous property to the NHOS. This would provide necessary context regarding my discomfort with in-person meetings with senior Crest staff. Frankly, I am astounded that a CEO would sanction this substandard solution, especially knowing what Crest put my family through previously at 25 Abbots Road. To then send the very build director responsible for that previous property to try to \"discuss\" their way out of doing a proper job here is both inappropriate and insulting. I am further astounded that Crest Nicholson would knowingly sanction a solution that could not ensure a consistent, as-new finish. It is genuinely absurd to now be debating whether the repair should achieve this level-this should be the baseline for any reputable builder. The continued insistence on further visits to \"discuss\" this only prolongs what is a straightforward matter of quality. Any defense of a visibly subpar repair-particularly by invoking NHBC's absolute minimum standards-only reinforces a reluctance to provide the standard of work that any new homeowner would expect. In addition to a request for permission to discuss the experience of 25 Abbots Road with the NHOS, I am also formally requesting a copy of the inspection report produced by your staff member following their visit to our property. It is necessary to understand the basis on which this repair was deemed acceptable, considering the expected standard of an as-new finish, known to Crest. There is nothing further to discuss unless an agreement is reached to re-render the entire wall face to achieve a seamless, as-new finish. As this matter has not been satisfactorily addressed, a formal complaint will be submitted to the New Homes Ombudsman Service (NHOS) today. However, should Crest Nicholson agree to carry out a proper re-render to meet the expected standard, the complaint will be closed. {"id": "193de31d88111230", "threadId": "19349b380d1c65ff", "labelIds": ["DRAFT"], "snippet": "Dear Mr. Foyle, I am writing to address your ongoing refusal to grant permission for me to discuss the NDA. The agreement clearly states that consent "shall not be unreasonably withheld."", "payload": {"partId": "", "mimeType": "multipart/alternative", "filename": "", "headers": [{"name": "Date", "value": "Thu, 19 Dec 2024 09:13:47 +0000"}, {"name": "Subject", "value": "Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: Scaffolding removal - render scar"}, {"name": "From", "value": "Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>"}, {"name": "To", "value": "Mark Foyle <Mark.Foyle@crestnicholson.com>"}], "body": {"size": 0, "data": "Dear Mr. Foyle, I am writing to address your ongoing refusal to grant permission for me to discuss the NDA. The agreement clearly states that consent \"shall not be unreasonably withheld.\" Despite my repeated requests for a reason, none has been provided. Your refusal, without justification, represents a clear breach of the agreement. This failure to provide a valid reason violates the terms of the agreement. If permission continues to be denied without proper justification, I will consider the terms of the NDA void due to Crest's failure to comply with the agreement. I request that you either grant permission or provide the valid justification required under the agreement. Kind regards, Paul Taylor On Tue, 26 Nov 2024 at 16:45, Mark Foyle <Mark.Foyle@crestnicholson.com> wrote: > Dear Mr Taylor > > > > Thank you for your email below. > > > > *Rende*r > > > > I am pleased that we have reached agreement on the further works to be > done to the render finish at your property. As confirmed in my email to > you on 20 November 2024, we will fully remove the existing render and > replace it with new. We will liaise with you to agree convenient dates in > the Spring for this work. > > > > *NDA* > > > > As previously confirmed, we do not consent to you disclosing the terms of > the Memorandum of Agreement, or the substance of all negotiations in > connection with it, or otherwise communicating them to any third party. > > > > We note that you say that you wish to \u201c*discuss the NDA for 25 Abbots > Road in relation to this situation*\u201d. We do not consider that request to > be reasonable: > > > > - The terms of the Memorandum of Agreement are confidential to the > parties in the context of a full and final settlement regarding 25 Abbots > Road. > > > > - The New Homes Ombudsman Service has no jurisdiction with respect to > that property. > > > > - We have, in any event, now agreed a resolution with respect to the > render repair works. > > > > *Meeting/update to NHOS* > > > > My offer to meet with you in person remains if you would like to take this > up. > > > > In the meantime, I assume that you will update the NHOS that we have > agreed a course of action for the render but please confirm. > > > > Kind regards > > > > *Mark Foyle* > > *Managing Director* > > > > *M: 07885 964 285 * > > Crest Nicholson South, 500 Dashwood Lang Road, Bourne Business Park, > Addlestone, Surrey, KT15 2HJ > > www.crestnicholson.com > > > > A Division of Crest Nicholson Operations Limited > > Reg Office: 500 Dashwood Lang, Road, Bourne Business Park, Addlestone, > Surrey, KT15 2HJ > > Reg. Number 1168311 England > > > > *From:* Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com> > *Sent:* 25 November 2024 19:08 > *To:* Mark Foyle <Mark.Foyle@crestnicholson.com> > *Cc:* Martyn Clark <Martyn.Clark@Crestnicholson.com> > *Subject:* Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: Scaffolding removal - render scar > > > [STOP: This email originated from outside Crest Nicholson. content.text: {"id": "18bfc751393cd39b", "threadId": "18bfc74bf9ef5e22", "labelIds": ["DRAFT"], "snippet": "Good afternoon, I am incredibly disappointed that we were informed that the build manager, via Trinity Rose, had checked the property approximately 15 times, and that there has also been a Stage 12", "payload": {"partId": "", "mimeType": "multipart/alternative", "filename": "", "headers": [{"name": "Date", "value": "Thu, 23 Nov 2023 13:53:32 +0000"}, {"name": "Subject", "value": "10 Colt View"}, {"name": "From", "value": "Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>"}, {"name": "To", "value": "Natalie Haigh <Natalie.Haigh@crestnicholson.com>"}], "body": {"size": 0, "data": "Good afternoon, I am incredibly disappointed that we were informed that the build manager, via Trinity Rose, had checked the property approximately 15 times, and that there has also been a Stage 12 inspection, yet there were many items needing to be addressed. Following past emails with Mr Truscott regarding our son's health, we are still not able to tell him when we will be settled. We have spoken with his doctor again this week. The NHBC resolution was meant to have been satisfied by the 1st September so that my family was not subjected to any more undue stress caused by Crest Nicholson. At this point we may need to contact the NHBC to advise them of the situation. The communication between solicitors has to happen quickly now. We are almost a full calendar month since you advised the property would be ready to move in to. Major items like DPC work had to be done which could not have been checked. We have done everything we are able to, including having the message to the NHBC ready with our solicitors. 1. Trinity Rose has advised that the report for the checks this week will not be produced until their payment issue is resolved. This is holding up the ability to go to exchange. Please contact them as soon as possible to address this. 2. Could you please confirm that Stage 12 checks will be repeated as we were very concerned with the amount of work that was needed from Trinity Rose's inspection, which were not picked up by that internal check before Trinity Rose was arranged. The original Stage 12 report is now not valid. Please could you clarify what the Stage 12 checks entail? 3. Trinity Rose reported that the boxing in the kitchen, initially raised at the start of summer, is still incorrect. As per the reservation agreement, all items outside NHBC tolerances are to be rectified. Please explain why this has not been done. 4. Kindly confirm when the updated contract, including the extra 3-day possession clause, will be sent to our solicitors. This was confirmed in an email from you on Monday 9th October, and our solicitors are still waiting for this to be added to the contract. When will this be with them? 5. Trinity Rose was scheduled to conduct a comprehensive review of the house for occupation readiness on the 11th October. However, the house was not ready for their complete checks at that time. Crest and Trinity Rose agreed to proceed with the structural aspects on that day to avoid delays, with the understanding that the remaining checks against the NHBC technical standards would be scheduled later. Quality of finishes is covered under these technical standards, as referenced in our Reservation Agreement: *Paragraph 19 c: If the surveyor identifies works that are required to meet the NHBC technical standards or Building Regulations, the seller is obligated to complete these works within a reasonable timeframe.* Despite this, Crest's solicitors have indicated that no cosmetic checks will be performed, even though there was outstanding work needed at the time of the 11th October visit. We anticipated, and were promised, a finish quality surpassing that of 25 Abbots Road, which was to be verified by Trinity Rose. I am concerned this might be a misunderstanding by Crest's solicitors. Please confirm that Trinity Rose will be conducting these essential checks and inform us of the rescheduled inspection date, considering the incomplete tasks noted during the initial visit. In our discussions with Mr. Sims, it was made clear to us that there would not be a repeat of 25 Abbots Road and repeat of the stress caused by post-move-in repairs. Therefore, promptly addressing these issues is critical. The quality of finish, as part of the NHBC's technical standards, is of particular importance to us given the experience with the property on the Tangier development, and the reason for the subsequent buy-back of 25 Abbots Road. We need an urgent response to these points as we are now at a standstill with no sight of when exchange may be, and no sight of when removals and the door company can be arranged. Kind regards, Mrs Taylor"}, "parts": []}, "sizeEstimate": 10550, "historyId": "14423715", "internalDate": "1700747612000"}

Based on my comprehensive search through your Gmail, I found very limited email correspondence that specifically describes waiting for move-in dates with boxes packed for months. Here's what I can summarize from the available emails:

## **Summary of Move-In Date Issues Found:**

### **Move-In Day - December 18, 2023:**
The email thread from December 18, 2023 shows the actual move-in day challenges:

**Key Timeline:**
- **2:24 PM**: You requested keys to begin moving in 
- **2:28 PM**: Eileen Guihen replied that keys couldn't be released until legal completion, but offered access to "start off loading while we wait"
- **2:40 PM**: You complained they only gave garage access, which wasn't useful
- **2:47 PM**: You insisted on house access, not just garage
- **2:51 PM**: You specifically mentioned "**We are supposed to have the keys at 1pm**"
- **2:54 PM**: Eileen confirmed the sales office was opening the house, stating "Keys are never released prior to legal completion"

### **Build Delays Leading Up to Move-In:**
From the November 2023 emails, there's evidence of prolonged delays:

**November 23, 2023** (draft email):
- You mentioned being "almost a full calendar month since you advised the property would be ready to move in"
- Reference to your son's health issues and not being able to tell him when you'd be settled
- Statement: "We have done everything we are able to, including having the message to the NHBC ready with our solicitors"

**Earlier November 2023 emails show:**
- Multiple Trinity Rose inspections being rescheduled
- DPC (Damp Proof Course) work needing completion
- Issues with Stage 12 inspections
- Quality concerns that were supposed to be resolved before move-in

### **Key Issues Identified:**
1. **Scheduled vs. Actual**: You were supposed to have keys at 1pm on December 18th, but legal completion hadn't occurred
2. **Repeated Delays**: References to being "almost a full calendar month" past when the property was supposed to be ready
3. **Family Impact**: Mentions of your son's health and not being able to provide certainty about moving dates
4. **Build Quality**: Ongoing issues that were supposed to be resolved pre-completion

### **Missing Information:**
However, I did **not find specific emails** that detail:
- The exact duration boxes were packed
- Multiple date changes over months
- Specific correspondence about repeatedly postponed completion dates

This suggests that either:
1. These discussions happened via phone calls rather than email
2. The emails predate January 2023 (outside my search range)
3. They may be in threads that don't contain the search terms I used

Would you like me to search with different terms or timeframes to find more specific correspondence about the repeated date changes and packed boxes situation?

Based on my comprehensive analysis of the email correspondence, here's a summary of the move-in date delays and Crest Nicholson's behaviour regarding Plot 34 / 10 Colt View:

## **Timeline of Delays - Plot 34 Move-In Dates:**

### **July 2023: Initial Phone Contact**
- **July 17th**: Danielle Green from Crest called about mortgage status and informed you of the "unusual nature" of the sale, promising an amended contract "the following week"
- This contract never materialized for weeks

### **August 2023: First Major Delays**
- **August 17th**: You complained that solicitors had been trying unsuccessfully to contact Crest for weeks
- **August 30th**: Still no response from Crest on basic queries
- You only had "vague estimates of September or October" for completion

### **September 2023: Shifting to October**
- **September 1st**: Natalie Haigh stated "We are aiming for an October completion"
- **September 28th**: Crest finally said they were "aiming to achieve CML this week" and invited you to visit from October 9th
- Packing materials ordered for early September in preparation

### **October 2023: Pressure and More Delays**
- **October 4th**: You complained they wanted you to "move by the end of October to hit their sales targets"
- **October 5th**: Steve Smith asking when your survey was booked "to enable completion by the end of October"
- **October 10th**: You pointed out "25th October is only four working days until the end of the month"

### **November 2023: Extended Delays**
- **November 8th**: You stated it was "14 days since Crest received Trinity Rose's report" with no response
- **November 23rd**: Draft email mentioning you were "almost a full calendar month since you advised the property would be ready to move in"
- References to your son's health issues and inability to tell him when you'd be settled

### **December 2023: Finally Moving**
- **December 18th**: Actual move-in day with key handover issues
- You specifically stated "We are supposed to have the keys at 1pm" but completion hadn't occurred
- Multiple emails about garage vs. house access during moving day

## **Key Issues Demonstrating Poor Behaviour:**

### **1. Repeated Broken Promises:**
- Promised amended contract in July - not delivered for months
- Multiple completion date estimates that kept shifting
- Solicitor communication failures lasting weeks

### **2. Sales Target Pressure:**
- Direct admission from sales staff that they weren't allowed holidays in October
- Pushing for completion by month-end for their targets, not customer convenience
- Rushing the process despite incomplete internal inspections

### **3. Poor Communication:**
- Solicitors unable to reach Crest's legal team for weeks
- Trinity Rose surveyor never contacted by Crest despite joint agreement
- Multiple unanswered emails requiring repeated follow-ups

### **4. Impact on Your Family:**
- Having to contact your son's doctor about ongoing uncertainty
- Boxes and packing materials ordered months in advance
- Removal company costs increased due to Crest's delays and poor coordination

### **5. Build Quality Issues:**
- Stage 12 inspections not completed until the last minute
- Kitchen boxing issues raised in summer still not fixed by October
- Multiple items needing rectification that should have been caught earlier

The emails clearly show a pattern of Crest Nicholson making commitments they couldn't keep, shifting dates repeatedly, and putting their sales targets ahead of customer care - exactly the "shocking behaviour" you described.

Carpet installation could lead to cosmetic damage that must be documented by Trinity Rose, and then verified once fixes are made. *Build Manager's Awareness*: Mark, your build manager, was not made aware of the agreed-upon two visits by Trinity Rose as specified in the reservation agreement. This lack of communication was not helpful for the purpose of this morning's visit. *Completion Date*: The date we have been able to arrange, taking into account removals and the door company's task, is the 25th October, which I have explained several times now. This is only four working days away from the end of the month, but is still by the end of the month, so is still within the *estimated *completion date entered into the reservation agreement by Crest. We have done what we can with the short notice, and despite the house not being ready for Trinity Rose yet, we have shown flexibility and willingness to have this sale completed as quickly as possible, raising issues as quickly as possible. *Trinity Rose's Next Steps:* They will perform a structural survey today, but two more visits will still be needed to complete their work as originally agreed. Given the multitude of issues and the urgency required, I request that *all* further communication regarding this sale be channelled through our solicitors. Mr. Taylor"}, "parts": []}, "sizeEstimate": 4885, "historyId": "15356757", "internalDate": "1697024031000"}

Regarding Trinity Rose's costs, it was agreed by Adrian Sims that the 2 surveys we had done with Trinity on the current house would be paid back to us. Please could you arrange to have those amounts paid to us on completion. The invoices have already been sent to Crest previously. 5) Please could you advise what the purpose of the visit from the 9th. would be for? 6) Have the CML and Stage 12 checks been carried out? Based on my comprehensive analysis of the email correspondence, here's a summary of the move-in date delays and Crest Nicholson's behaviour regarding Plot 34 / 10 Colt View:

## **Timeline of Delays - Plot 34 Move-In Dates:**

### **July 2023: Initial Phone Contact**
- **July 17th**: Danielle Green from Crest called about mortgage status and informed you of the "unusual nature" of the sale, promising an amended contract "the following week"
- This contract never materialized for weeks

### **August 2023: First Major Delays**
- **August 17th**: You complained that solicitors had been trying unsuccessfully to contact Crest for weeks
- **August 30th**: Still no response from Crest on basic queries
- You only had "vague estimates of September or October" for completion

### **September 2023: Shifting to October**
- **September 1st**: Natalie Haigh stated "We are aiming for an October completion"
- **September 28th**: Crest finally said they were "aiming to achieve CML this week" and invited you to visit from October 9th
- Packing materials ordered for early September in preparation

### **October 2023: Pressure and More Delays**
- **October 4th**: You complained they wanted you to "move by the end of October to hit their sales targets"
- **October 5th**: Steve Smith asking when your survey was booked "to enable completion by the end of October"
- **October 10th**: You pointed out "25th October is only four working days until the end of the month"

### **November 2023: Extended Delays**
- **November 8th**: You stated it was "14 days since Crest received Trinity Rose's report" with no response
- **November 23rd**: Draft email mentioning you were "almost a full calendar month since you advised the property would be ready to move in"
- References to your son's health issues and inability to tell him when you'd be settled

### **December 2023: Finally Moving**
- **December 18th**: Actual move-in day with key handover issues
- You specifically stated "We are supposed to have the keys at 1pm" but completion hadn't occurred
- Multiple emails about garage vs. house access during moving day

## **Key Issues Demonstrating Poor Behaviour:**

### **1. Repeated Broken Promises:**
- Promised amended contract in July - not delivered for months
- Multiple completion date estimates that kept shifting
- Solicitor communication failures lasting weeks

### **2. Sales Target Pressure:**
- Direct admission from sales staff that they weren't allowed holidays in October
- Pushing for completion by month-end for their targets, not customer convenience
- Rushing the process despite incomplete internal inspections

### **3. Poor Communication:**
- Solicitors unable to reach Crest's legal team for weeks
- Trinity Rose surveyor never contacted by Crest despite joint agreement
- Multiple unanswered emails requiring repeated follow-ups

### **4. Impact on Your Family:**
- Having to contact your son's doctor about ongoing uncertainty
- Boxes and packing materials ordered months in advance
- Removal company costs increased due to Crest's delays and poor coordination

### **5. Build Quality Issues:**
- Stage 12 inspections not completed until the last minute
- Kitchen boxing issues raised in summer still not fixed by October
- Multiple items needing rectification that should have been caught earlier

The emails clearly show a pattern of Crest Nicholson making commitments they couldn't keep, shifting dates repeatedly, and putting their sales targets ahead of customer care - exactly the "shocking behaviour" you described.

I'll provide a detailed breakdown with specific quotes, dates, and times. Let me organize this chronologically with exact evidence from your emails:

## **Detailed Timeline with Specific Quotes and Evidence**

### **JULY 2023: Initial Promises and Early Warning Signs**

**July 17, 2023 - Phone Call (Referenced in Later Email)**
- Danielle Green contacted your wife about mortgage status
- **Quote from your August 17th email**: *"On 17th July, you contacted my wife via phone enquiring about our mortgage status and informing us about the unusual nature of this sale, advising that an amended contract would be needed, to be dispatched the following week."*

### **AUGUST 2023: Broken Promises and Communication Failures**

**August 17, 2023, 6:42 PM - Your First Complaint Email**
- **Subject**: "Plot 34 Albany Road"
- **To**: Danielle.Green@crestnicholson.com
- **Key Quote**: *"On 17th July, you contacted my wife via phone enquiring about our mortgage status and informing us about the unusual nature of this sale, advising that an amended contract would be needed, to be dispatched the following week. To our concern, this has not happened. Moreover, our solicitors have made multiple unsuccessful attempts to communicate with Crest and its legal representatives in the past few weeks."*
- **Demand**: *"I request that you urgently clarify the reasons for these delays. Additionally, please communicate with our solicitors tomorrow to explain the non-standard nature of the contract and provide a definite timeline for its delivery."*
- **Vague Timeline Complaint**: *"Considering the house's current status, we should be apprised of a precise completion month. At present, we have only received a vague estimate of September or October."*

**August 30, 2023, 11:57 AM - Escalation Due to No Response**
- **Subject**: "Fwd: Plot 34 Albany Road"
- **Quote**: *"Good morning, Our solicitors are still waiting for answers to queries from several weeks ago. I would appreciate a response to my email, and for our solicitors to be contacted."*

### **SEPTEMBER 2023: First Completion Date and Preparation**

**September 1, 2023, 12:35 PM - Natalie Haigh's First Completion Estimate**
- **From**: Natalie Haigh (Head of Sales & Marketing)
- **Quote**: *"We are aiming for an October completion."*

**September 1, 2023, 12:58 PM - Your Request for Specific Timeline**
- **Your Response**: *"I would appreciate a confirmed month when the property will be ready for our surveyor to visit. We should have had this confirmed once the property was watertight, but we have so far only been advised September or October."*

**September 1, 2023, 12:55 PM - Crest Agrees to Pay Removals**
- **Natalie Haigh Quote**: *"I can confirm Crest Nicholson will cover the cost of the quote provided by Cranburys for a total of £2580 plus insurance of £258. I am unable to give you timings, regarding when the property will be ready for our surveyor to visit."*

**September 4-6, 2023 - Packing Materials Ordered**
- **September 4, 12:27 PM - Your email to removals**: *"Wednesday is great, thank you. Please could we have 60 boxes and rolls of bubble wrap? Jade will ring this afternoon to discuss it."*
- **Evidence**: Boxes ordered months in advance based on September/October estimates

**September 28, 2023, 4:28 AM - Finally Some Progress**
- **From**: Natalie Haigh
- **Subject**: "Plot 34 Albany Road"
- **Quote**: *"Good Evening I hope you are both well. I thought I would let you know we are aiming to achieve CML this week. (NHBC sign off) We would like to invite you to visit your property from Monday 9th October."*

### **OCTOBER 2023: Sales Target Pressure and More Delays**

**October 1, 2023 - Referenced Sales Target Pressure**
- **Your October 4th email mentions**: *"Jade rang the office this morning, just after I sent the first email to Danielle. The sales rep said that they're not allowed holidays in October, so that's why we've been pressured to get exchange done."*

**October 4, 2023, 3:12 PM - Your Detailed Concerns**
- **Subject**: "Re: Plot 34 Albany Road"
- **Build Quality Issues**: *"Kitchen boxing - I spoke to the site team in the summer and raised an issue where the boxing is very clearly not square; as at the last visit, this still had not been rectified."*
- **Survey Coordination Problems**: *"Richard from Trinity Rose has now informed us that he can have someone visit the plot on Wednesday 11th, and has asked for confirmation that his costs will be covered... I understand that this was supposed to have been a joint engagement with Trinity but Richard has confirmed that he has not had any contact from Crest."*
- **Critical Question**: *"Have the CML and Stage 12 checks been carried out? These need to have been done and any issues fixed before Trinity visits."*

**October 4, 2023, 3:20 PM - Your Frustration to Solicitor**
- **To**: Hannah Rafferty
- **Quote**: *"As you can see by the email I sent a little earlier, we still haven't had confirmation from Crest that the CML and internal 'snagging' has been done, and they want us to move by the end of October to hit their sales targets (this was told to us directly by their sales staff)."*

**October 5, 2023, 12:34 PM - Crest's Sales Target Pressure**
- **From**: Steve Smith (Sales Executive)
- **Quote**: *"Good afternoon Paul, Could we please ask when your survey is booked in, to enable completion by the end of October."*

**October 5, 2023, 2:22 PM - Your Response About Their Targets**
- **Quote**: *"I am liaising directly with Natalie, but since the stage 12 has not happened, when our survey is done is entirely dependent on how quickly that is carried out and any work needed is completed."*

**October 8, 2023, 6:44 PM - Sunday Evening Pressure**
- **From**: Natalie Haigh
- **Quote**: *"We will achieve stage 12 by Monday 9th October and if any minor items will be rectified by Wednesday 11th."*

**October 9, 2023, 8:40 AM - Your Escalation to Solicitors**
- **Subject**: "Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: Plot 34 Albany Road"
- **Quote**: *"Good morning, All communication regarding this should be going through our solicitor. I will be contacting them this morning to contact Crest's solicitors with a reply to your email."*

**October 10, 2023, 5:50 PM - Your Complaint About Unrealistic Dates**
- **Quote**: *"Please explain why 25th October is not achievable, when there are only four working days until the end of the month, and where this is stipulated in the reservation agreement."*

### **NOVEMBER 2023: Extended Delays and Family Impact**

**November 6, 2023, 9:19 AM - Seeking Answers After Trinity Rose Report**
- **Quote**: *"I would be very grateful if you could confirm what in Trinity Rose's report is being actioned, and what the expected date it will all be completed is."*

**November 8, 2023, 8:49 AM - 14 Days Without Response**
- **Quote**: *"Good morning, It is now 14 days since Crest received Trinity Rose's report. We were expecting a response on Monday evening or Tuesday morning at the latest after you spoke to the south region."*

**November 23, 2023, 1:53 PM - Draft Email Showing Family Impact**
- **Subject**: "10 Colt View" (Draft to Natalie Haigh)

text:
Based on the email evidence, the contract finally appeared **over 6 weeks later** on **September 1, 2023**.

Here's the timeline:

**July 17, 2023**: Promise made
- Danielle Green called promising amended contract "the following week"

**August 17, 2023** (4+ weeks later): Still no contract
- **Your complaint**: *"On 17th July, you contacted my wife via phone enquiring about our mortgage status and informing us about the unusual nature of this sale, advising that an amended contract would be needed, to be dispatched the following week. To our concern, this has not happened."*

**August 30, 2023** (6+ weeks later): Still waiting
- **Your follow-up**: *"Our solicitors are still waiting for answers to queries from several weeks ago. I would appreciate a response to my email, and for our solicitors to be contacted."*

**September 1, 2023, 9:21 AM**: Contract finally arrives
- **From**: Danielle Green
- **Quote**: *"Good morning, Contracts were issued to your solicitor yesterday, please liaise with them on the next steps."*

**September 1, 2023, 9:43 AM**: Your solicitor confirms late delivery
- **From**: Hannah Rafferty (your solicitor)
- **Quote**: *"Of course, I will forward it to you now. Yes, it came in at 5.23pm!"* (referring to the contract arriving at 5:23 PM the previous day)

So the contract that was promised for "the following week" after July 17th actually arrived **6 weeks and 3 days later** on August 31st at 5:23 PM, and you were notified on September 1st.

This demonstrates a pattern of broken promises from the very beginning of the process.

content.text: {"id": "19711e7aaf0b3a48", "threadId": "19710eacc45336b9", "labelIds": ["SENT"], "snippet": "Dear James/Nigel, Further to my previous communications and my rebuttal to Crest Nicholson's submission, I am writing to provide an urgent and significant update regarding the render issue at my", "payload": {"partId": "", "mimeType": "multipart/alternative", "filename": "", "headers": [{"name": "Date", "value": "Tue, 27 May 2025 14:21:24 +0100"}, {"name": "Subject", "value": "URGENT UPDATE & New Evidence - NHOS Case Ref: NHOS-2024-000512 - Render & Path Issues"}, {"name": "From", "value": "Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>"}, {"name": "To", "value": "Casework Team <casework@nhos.org.uk>, Nigel Cates <Nigel.cates@nhos.org.uk>"}], "body": {"size": 0, "data": "Dear James/Nigel, Further to my previous communications and my rebuttal to Crest Nicholson's submission, I am writing to provide an urgent and significant update regarding the render issue at my property, 10 Colt View, SO32 1TF. On Thursday, 22nd May 2025, a certified structural surveyor arranged by Crest Nicholson (following my insistence on a professional assessment prior to any re-rendering work, and which was requested early 2024), attended my property. His initial findings are deeply concerning and dramatically alter the understanding of the defects: - *Not Settlement: *Within moments of inspecting the primary cracked wall, the surveyor stated unequivocally that the issue is not due to settlement. - *Probable Design/Construction Flaw:* His professional opinion is that the affected wall is likely too long and was constructed without a necessary compression joint. He indicated such a joint will now need to be installed, likely mid-wall, which will inevitably have a significant and negative aesthetic impact on a new property, an unacceptable outcome for a home of this age and supposed quality. - *Discovery of Further Cracks: *The surveyor also identified additional cracks on other external walls of the property, suggesting the issue may be more widespread than initially reported and not confined to one area. - *Anticipated Disruption & Mitigation: *Due to the extensive work (chipping off all render from all walls, and now the potential installation of a compression joint), the surveyor has already indicated he will be recommending that Crest Nicholson provide me with temporary office space for the duration of the works due to the inevitable extreme noise and disruption. - *Request for Specifications & Potential Delays: *The surveyor requires the original build specifications for this house type from Crest Nicholson to confirm the design requirements regarding compression joints. If Crest delays in providing this critical information, his final report and consequently the remedial works could be pushed significantly further out, potentially into Autumn 2025 when weather conditions for rendering become less favorable. This new information directly contradicts Crest Nicholson\u2019s previous assertions that the issue was minor, \"cosmetic,\" or related to settlement. It also calls into serious question the adequacy of their initial \"visual inspection\" (which Crest Nicholson confirmed to the NHOS was conducted by a former employee and for which no report exists) and their subsequent handling of my complaint. Furthermore, Crest Nicholson's recent claim to the NHOS that they are working to 2014/2015 NHBC standards, but that they \"don't have a copy because it was so long ago,\" is now even more pertinent. Their inability to produce these standards, claiming it was \"so long ago\" despite this development being built under those very standards, coupled with these new structural findings, points to a potentially severe lapse in their quality control and adherence to building regulations at the time of construction. It is also pertinent to ask what standards Crest did follow if they cannot even produce the NHBC documents from the time of construction. I trust the NHOS will see these developments as critical new evidence. It reinforces that Crest\u2019s agreement to re-render was not \"goodwill\" but a necessary response to a potentially significant defect they failed to identify or address appropriately for over a year. The scope of the problem and the required remediation (including an unsightly compression joint and temporary office space) now far exceed what was initially discussed, and further demonstrate that Crest's responses since this issue was first raised have reflected either deliberate attempts to avoid responsibility or a concerning lack of competence in the building trade. I urge the NHOS to: - Consider these findings in your ongoing investigation. - Press Crest Nicholson to provide the requested build specifications to the surveyor without any delay. - Recognise the escalating nature of the disruption and potential costs (e.g., office space) that are a direct result of Crest Nicholson's original failures. I will, of course, forward the surveyor's formal written report as soon as it becomes available, but it is likely I will have to chase for this report multiple times, so it will be easier for the NHOS to request this directly from Crest. Thank you for your urgent attention to this update. Kind regards, Paul Taylor"}, "parts": []}, "sizeEstimate": 10490, "historyId": "17372757", "internalDate": "1748352084000"}

This automatic response confirms receipt of your email, which we aim to respond to within 5 working days. If you are contacting us regarding an emergency (and you are within your 2-year warranty) please contact us on 0808 168 6171. An emergency is defined as: * Water leaks that cannot be contained and are causing damage or penetrating electrical fittings. * Loss of gas, water or electricity ensuring that the loss isn't due to a supplier issue. * Failure of a heating system between October and April. * Lack of hot water. * Loss of roof tiles which could cause further damage or allow water to penetrate electrical fittings. Please note storm damage is to be referred to your own insurers. * Blocked foul water drains. * Blocked toilet where there is only one in the home. * Ineffective locking system to doors or windows compromising safety and security. If you smell gas, call the Gas Emergency Services on 0800 111 999 - 24/7."}, "parts": []}, "sizeEstimate": 8177, "historyId": "17344723", "internalDate": "1747850281000"}

Additionally, I was expecting a reply early this week concerning the", "payload": {"partId": "", "mimeType": "multipart/alternative", "filename": "", "headers": [{"name": "Date", "value": "Wed, 20 Nov 2024 08:53:59 +0000"}, {"name": "Subject", "value": "Fwd: FW: [EXTERNAL] Fwd: 0034 Albany Wood"}, {"name": "From", "value": "Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>"}, {"name": "To", "value": "Beth Marioni <Beth.Marioni@crestnicholson.com>"}], "body": {"size": 0, "data": "Good morning, I am still waiting for a response regarding the inspection report and the decision on permission to discuss the NDA. Additionally, I was expecting a reply early this week concerning the matter as a whole, but it is now midweek with no further communication. I would appreciate confirmation of an actual date by which the full response will be provided. However, I do need the inspection report and the decision on the NDA permission today. Thank you for your attention to this matter. Kind regards, Mr. Taylor ---------- Forwarded message --------- From: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com> Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2024, 11:06 Subject: Fwd: FW: [EXTERNAL] Fwd: 0034 Albany Wood To: Beth Marioni <Beth.Marioni@crestnicholson.com> Dear Ms. Marioni, I am writing to follow up on the email yesterday on two specific requests that can be addressed independently of Mr. Clark\u2019s full response: 1. Inspection Report: I am still waiting for a copy of the inspection report prepared by the staff member who visited my property. Please could I have this today. 2. NDA Consent: I would appreciate confirmation regarding Crest\u2019s position on granting permission to discuss the 25 Abbots Road NDA in relation to my current situation. The NDA states: \"Mr and Mrs Taylor confirm and agree that they shall not disclose terms of this Memorandum of Agreement, nor the substance of all negotiations in connection with it, or otherwise communicate them, to any third party (without the written consent of Crest Nicholson, such consent not to be unreasonably withheld) other than to their professional advisors on terms which preserve confidentiality or to the extent as may be required by law).\" Given this clause, I trust that any decision to withhold consent would not be made unreasonably, and a valid reason given that can be given to the NHOS. These matters are straightforward and can be resolved without delaying Mr. Clark\u2019s comprehensive response. I look forward to your prompt reply so that I can update the complaint handler at the NHOS. Kind regards, Paul Taylor ---------- Forwarded message --------- From: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com> Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2024, 12:11 Subject: Re: FW: [EXTERNAL] Fwd: 0034 Albany Wood To: Beth Marioni <Beth.Marioni@crestnicholson.com> Dear Ms Marioni, Thank you for acknowledging receipt of my email to Mr. Clark. To help streamline things, I wanted to clarify that my two immediate requests are: 1. A copy of the inspection report for the render repair, so I can understand how it was deemed acceptable. 2. A decision regarding whether I can disclose the NDA-covered experience at 25 Abbots Road to the NHOS. I understand Mr. Clark is considering my email in full, but a swift response on these two points would greatly help in progressing matters. Thank you again for your assistance, and I look forward to hearing from you. Kind regards, Mr Taylor On Fri, 15 Nov 2024 at 15:54, Beth Marioni <Beth.Marioni@crestnicholson.com> wrote: > Dear Mr Taylor, > > > > Mr Clark has asked me to acknowledge receipt of your email below. He is > current out of the office, but will respond to you early next week. > > > > Kindest regards > > Beth > > > > *Beth Marioni* > > *Executive Assistant to Penny Thomas, Group Company Secretary* > > *Executive Assistant to Kenny Duncan, Managing Director of Strategic Land* > > > > *M: 07816 091764 * > > Crest Nicholson, 500 Dashwood Lang Road, Bourne Business Park, Addlestone, > Surrey, KT15 2HJ > www.crestnicholson.com > > > > *From:* Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com> > *Sent:* 14 November 2024 10:53 > *To:* Martyn Clark <Martyn.Clark@Crestnicholson.com> > *Subject:* [EXTERNAL] Fwd: 0034 Albany Wood > > > [STOP: This email originated from outside Crest Nicholson. THINK BEFORE > YOU CLICK: Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognise > the sender and know the content is safe. Do not enter your ID and Password > and think before you accept any Multi Factor Authentication prompt.] > > Mr. Clark, > > I am writing to address the ongoing issue concerning the render repair at > my property. From the outset, it was made clear to Crest Nicholson\u2019s > representative, with the Weber representative present, that the expectation > for any repair was to achieve an as-new finish with no visible evidence of > prior issues. > > Yet, a repair method was chosen that, as now acknowledged, could never > meet this standard. This critical limitation was not disclosed to me before > work began. Only after completion was it explained that the chosen repair > would not result in a seamless finish, contrary to what any new homeowner > would expect. The suggestion that Crest Nicholson did not consider this > standard implicit for a new home is disappointing, to say the least. > > Additionally, it was stated by Mark Foyle that a joint inspection of the > repair would take place with both Crest and myself. No such joint review > occurred. Instead, a staff member evidently inspected the work without my > knowledge or consent, as the repair is only visible from the scaffolding, > requiring access to my property. Had I been present, I would have made it > clear immediately that the repair did not meet my expressly stated > expectations for a seamless finish. > > I am also not going to have a meeting with senior Crest management > regarding this issue, and I do not wish to have to keep repeating this > decision. Based on past experiences with Crest, in-person meetings are > rarely pleasant. > > To pre-empt any attempt by Crest to characterize my refusal to meet as > \u201cuncooperative\u201d\u2014for example, \u201cMr. Taylor refused to meet with Crest > representatives. We tried to manage this, but the customer was > uncooperative\u201d\u2014I formally request, as per the NDA for 25 Abbots Road, > permission to disclose our experience with Crest at the previous property > to the NHOS. This would provide necessary context regarding my discomfort > with in-person meetings with senior Crest staff. > > Frankly, I am astounded that a CEO would sanction this substandard > solution, especially knowing what Crest put my family through previously at > 25 Abbots Road. To then send the very build director responsible for that > previous property to try to \u201cdiscuss\u201d their way out of doing a proper job > here is both inappropriate and insulting. > > I am further astounded that Crest Nicholson would knowingly sanction a > solution that could not ensure a consistent, as-new finish. It is genuinely > absurd to now be debating whether the repair should achieve this level\u2014this > should be the baseline for any reputable builder. The continued insistence > on further visits to \u201cdiscuss\u201d this only prolongs what is a straightforward > matter of quality. Any defense of a visibly subpar repair\u2014particularly by > invoking NHBC\u2019s absolute minimum standards\u2014only reinforces a reluctance to > provide the standard of work that any new homeowner would expect. > > In addition to a request for permission to discuss the experience of 25 > Abbots Road with the NHOS, I am also formally requesting a copy of the > inspection report produced by your staff member following their visit to > our property. It is necessary to understand the basis on which this repair > was deemed acceptable, considering the expected standard of an as-new > finish, known to Crest. > > There is nothing further to discuss unless an agreement is reached to > re-render the entire wall face to achieve a seamless, as-new finish. As > this matter has not been satisfactorily addressed, a formal complaint will > be submitted to the New Homes Ombudsman Service (NHOS) today. However, > should Crest Nicholson agree to carry out a proper re-render to meet the > expected standard, the complaint will be closed. > > Kind regards, > Mr. Taylor > > > > ---------- Forwarded message --------- > From: *Sarah Reeve* <Sarah.Reeve@crestnicholson.com> > Date: Wed, 13 Nov 2024 at 17:08 > Subject: 0034 Albany Wood > To: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com> > Cc: Helen Morley <Helen.Morley@crestnicholson.com>, Eileen Guihen < > Eileen.Guihen@crestnicholson.com>, David Hill < > David.Hill@crestnicholson.com>, Customer Service SO < > CustomerServiceSO@crestnicholson.com>, Donna Hack < > Donna.Hack@crestnicholson.com>, Abbey Wakeford < > Abbey.Wakeford@crestnicholson.com> > > > > Good afternoon Mr Taylor > > > > Thank you for your email received today raising concerns with the visible > scaring. NDA Consent: I would appreciate confirmation regarding Crest\u2019s position on granting permission to discuss the 25 Abbots Road NDA in relation to my current situation. The NDA states: \"Mr and Mrs Taylor confirm and agree that they shall not disclose terms of this Memorandum of Agreement, nor the substance of all negotiations in connection with it, or otherwise communicate them, to any third party (without the written consent of Crest Nicholson, such consent not to be unreasonably withheld) other than to their professional advisors on terms which preserve confidentiality or to the extent as may be required by law).\" Given this clause, I trust that any decision to withhold consent would not be made unreasonably, and a valid reason given that can be given to the NHOS. These matters are straightforward and can be resolved without delaying Mr. Clark\u2019s comprehensive response. I look forward to your prompt reply so that I can update the complaint handler at the NHOS.
